CaseAppointments.InquestNarrativeConclusion:
Melvin Sturges attended work on 3rd October 2023. He assisted a colleague with a vehicle he was familiar with. He climbed a ladder on the side of the vehicle (M535), on descent he missed the bottom step, stumbled and fell onto his left side. He was taken to Bedford Hospital South Wing. Melvin was diagnosed with a fractured femur and underwent surgery on 4th October 2023. He was transferred to the Reginald Hart ward on 9th October 2023. Melvin was declared medically optimised for discharge on 16th October 2023 after receiving treatment. On 18th October 2023 Melvin was assessed and showed no signs for concerns. Around 5pm, Melvin was visited by a friend and Melvin was complaining of chest pains. He was attended to by medical staff. He suffered cardiac arrest and became unresponsive. Resuscitation teams were deployed but attempts to resuscitate were unsuccessful. 

Melvin Sturges was pronounced dead on 18th October 2023. 

A Post Mortem showed Melvin had suffered a Pulmonary Thromboembolism after developing a deep vein thrombosis likely due to the inability caused by the fractured femur and subsequent surgery.

CaseAppointments.InquestNarrativeConclusion:
In the evening of 4 April 2024, the deceased visited her cousin. She complained of feeling tightness in her chest and being more breathless than usual. She was advised by her cousin to call 111 when she got home and an ambulance if she got worse. The deceasedâ€™s brother picked her up because she told him she was unwell, and he drove her home. The next day, on 5 April 2011, after receiving no reply to his text message, her brother went to the deceased house where he found her collapsed on the floor. There were signs of drug use in the lounge and there were empty alcohol bottles in the deceased bedroom. She was pronounced dead at 18:40 by paramedics. 

The deceased had accessed mental health services. She had been diagnosed with Emotionally Unstable Personality Disorder, Recurrent Depressive Disorder and ADHD, and had a history substance misuse of cocaine. She was not an intravenous drug user. She was prescribed and took medication for her depression and for ADHD. There was a family history of fatal cardiac arrests. This family history and long term cocaine use, along with taking prescription medication for ADHD (which contained a type of amphetamine) are factors which are likely to have contributed to the acute cardiotoxicity which caused her death.

CaseAppointments.InquestNarrativeConclusion: It is believed that the failure to call OSCAR 1 after the telephone cord incident directly impacted Steven and this did not allow for a further ACCT review to take place and enable the removal of ligature material to be assessed, support to be put in place, observations to be increased and a full risk assessment to be carried out. Items could have been removed to prevent further self harm or suicide attempts by Steven had this been facilitated by contacting OSCAR1. It is unclear from the evidence given whether Steven would have been placed on constant observations as this is assessed on a case by case basis. It would appear from the earlier incident on 25th March 2023 that Steven's mental health was deteriorating and in fact he was looking for an opportunity to hurt himself or end his life. There is no evidence available to suggest whether the metal observation panel was broken prior to 25th March 2023. It is the belief of the jury that the checks seen in the CCTV were not carried out to the proper standard and it is the belief that there was a failure to inform the healthcare team of the telephone ligature attempt.

CaseAppointments.InquestNarrativeConclusion:
On 16 May 2024, the deceased was diagnosed with malignant epithelioid mesothelioma following a biopsy. He was treated with immunotherapy but in November 2024 he was not well enough to continue with the treatment. On 4 December 2024, an MRI scan showed an aggressive presumed dural base lesion with extensive oedema (a brain tumour). 

The deceased worked as a painter and decorator for most of his life. It is likely that he was exposed to asbestos during his employment for approximately thirty years. He died of a malignant brain tumour, but also suffered from malignant mesothelioma and chronic lymphocytic leukaemia which contributed to his death.

CaseAppointments.InquestNarrativeConclusion: At around 07.00 hours on 19 January 2025, the Deceased suffered an unwitnessed fall from the bottom stair at his step-daughter's home in Luton.  Although, initially, he did not appear to have been injured, on returning home, he was struggling to speak and mobilise properly and was immediately admitted to East Surrey Hospital where a CT head scan revealed he had suffered a large acute on chronic subdural haematoma.  The neurosurgeons advised against intervention and he passed away at the hospital on 20 January 2025; his death being confirmed at 07.15 hours.

CaseAppointments.InquestNarrativeConclusion: It is believed that the failure to call OSCAR 1 after the telephone cord incident directly impacted Steven and this did not allow for a further ACCT review to take place and enable the removal of ligature material to be assessed, support to be put in place, observations to be increased and a full risk assessment to be carried out. Items could have been removed to prevent further self harm or suicide attempts by Steven had this been facilitated by contacting OSCAR1. It is unclear from the evidence given whether Steven would have been placed on constant observations as this is assessed on a case by case basis. It would appear from the earlier incident on 25th March 2023 that Steven's mental health was deteriorating and in fact he was looking for an opportunity to hurt himself or end his life. There is no evidence available to suggest whether the metal observation panel was broken prior to 25th March 2023. It is the belief of the jury that the checks seen in the CCTV were not carried out to the proper standard and it is the belief that there was a failure to inform the healthcare team of the telephone ligature attempt.
